awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Linking Within-Host and Between-Host Infectious Disease Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Infectious diseases, such as malaria and influenza-like illnesses, are leading causes of sickness and mortality among humans and wild and domestic animals.  There is considerable data available on the effects of pathogens within a single host individual and the resulting responses of the host immune system, and also for the distribution of the infectious diseases within host populations (for example, the total number of infections and the rates of new infections).  Pathogen abundance within a host can rise after infection, and then wane to the point of extinction because of host immune responses.  This project will create mathematical models that link such within-host pathogen dynamics to the spread of pathogens between hosts.  These models will make use of both sources of data, leading to a better understanding of these infectious diseases and therefore possible strategies for their control.  For example, these types of models have shown that HIV medications decrease HIV levels within patients, increasing patient lifespan, which can perversely result in more HIV cases in the population as a whole.  Sufficiently wide-spread application of these medications, however, may decrease the number of cases.  Using multi-scale data validates these models and allows their application to make predictions in cases where population data is scant.  The models that will be developed can be used to assess how the pathogen load within a host affects the number of disease cases and the effect of control measures such as medications and vaccination on the number of cases.  Most infectious diseases that still to this day create significant death, particularly among humans, are caused by pathogens that can evolve very quickly; hosts can also evolve in response to these pathogens.  Models that link within-host and between-host data are particularly adept for studying host and pathogen evolution, adding a new dimension to our understanding of how to control diseases with pathogens that can change rapidly, such as malaria, hepatitis C, and influenza.

The central research objectives of this project are: (1) Develop, analyze and simulate multi-scale mathematical models that link immunology, epidemiology and ecology in vector-borne diseases or diseases involving ecologically interacting species, and that are well grounded in disease epidemiology, ecology and immunology. (2) Develop mathematical techniques to analyze multi-scale models and study disease evolution using these models. Develop numerical techniques to fit such models to data, thus integrating immunological and epidemiological data. (3) Use immuno-epidemiological models to address important questions related to control and evolution of vector-borne diseases and diseases involving ecologically interacting species. In particular, two types of questions will be addressed: (a) How do within-host dynamics affect the population level reproduction number and disease prevalence and what consequences does that have for the control of infectious diseases? (b) How do pathogens and hosts evolve in their within-host interactions to enhance their population level performance?

por.por_cntn:
We have developed and studied multi-scale immuno-epidemiological models of vector-borne diseases, such as Rift Valley fever, Leishmaniasis, malaria, and others. To obtain credible results from such models we first addressed the problem of obtaining the parameters for the models from both immunological and epidemiological time series data. We developed the techniques for studying practical identifiability of the multi-scale models and we found out that fitting those models  simultaneously leads to better identification of the parameters as opposed to fitting the immunological model first  and the epidemiological model second. This observation is very important because available data sets can be more efficiently utilized. The resulting software has been provided for general  use in github.

 

Further, we show that evolution  of the pathogen works to maximize the population-level  basic reproduction number, while evolution of the host works to minimize the case-fatality proportion, which measures the proportion of host deaths from the disease in all host deaths. We further found that the vector innoculum size increases the basic reproduction number of the disease but can either increase or disease the case-fatality proportion.

 

Several of our investigations suggest  that multi-scale systems are more stable than single scale systems; more over stabilization from the lower to the upper scale may occur. In a malaria model we showed that the immunological scale exhibits complex dynamical behavior as oscillations and chaos while the epidemiological scale shows  stability and convergence to a steady state.

 

Backward bifurcation is an important phenomenon that allows for persistence of the disease even if its reproduction number is lower than one. Because of the importance of this phenomenon, mathematical tools have been developed in the past to determine necessary and sufficient conditions for backward bifurcation to occur. These necessary and sufficient conditions can be used to guide control strategies to become more effective. Most tools work for ordinary differential equation models but we have developed a new methodology for deriving necessary and sufficient conditions for backward bifurcation which works for partial differential equation model and in particular for nested multi-scale immuno-epidemiological models. This methodology increases the available tool set for studying multi-scale immuno-epidemiological models and their implications for disease control.

 

We developed and analyzed for the first time a multi-scale model where each scale depends on the other (bidirectionally linked). We developed the mathematical techniques to show that the models exhibit oscillations on both scales. We found that the very complex multi-scale partial differential equation model is dynamically similar to a simple three equation ordinary differential equation  model, which was used as a tool to find the complex behavior in the partial differential equation  model. Such models can be used to capture many multi-scale phenomena such as environmental diseases in humans (cholera),  diseases in animal and plants, and others, and the tools and techniques developed as a part of this project have paved the road for their use.

 

Treatment with medication for vector-borne diseases, when available, can be an effective measure to alleviate symptoms on the individual level and eliminate the disease from population on epidemiological level. Our simulations suggest, however, that treatment should be applied as early as possible and as strongly as possible  to lead to disease eradication.

 

This award has lead to 25 publications, including one book, 30-40 talks and poster presentations. We have organized three special sessions where we have reported our results and discussed others' results on multi-scaled modeling. The award has helped train 2 PhD students  and 2 undergraduate students at University of Florida.
